subNodes.conversationText: [Right before the sun rises, the fire of the Flame Stone flickers brightly and then, all of a sudden, dies.]
[No one says a word, but the feeling of despair in the air is palpable. Meanwhile, the sound of approaching troops grows from audible to deafening.]
[The two forces converge on the Flame Stone clearing at the same time.]
[They halt on opposite ends of the circle.]
[A woman, the commander of the Zhentarim forces, steps forward. She speaks in a loud, demanding voice--]

I am Kevis, High Priestess of Bane and emissary of Zhentil Keep. It appears that the reports were true: the force that cost us Darkhold would be here, as would the pathetic opposition you might expect--self-important knights of Sune and a group of adventurers. Surrender yourselves, all of you, or you will all perish.
Why do you come here?  This place is holy to Sune.  Bane cannot touch it.

We come here for revenge. We also mean to recapture Darkhold: this is to be the first stroke of many. The quarrel we have with the group that calls itself the Risen Sun does not include you--or, at least, it didn't.
[Shouting to the force opposite her own.] Sun-worshippers! Hypocrites! Deceivers! What have you to say for yourselves?
[The Risen Sun remains silent as an old, bent man walks through their ranks to the front of the line.]

[The voice of the man is gentle, almost a whisper, but somehow it carries across the clearing.] I am called Theophilus, Sunlord of Amaunator. Why do you trouble us, dwellers in the shadow? You have no claim to this place, as these good knights to my right believe they do.
You will answer for taking Darkhold from us!

Nay, you poor, unrepentant woman. Darkhold--Sunhold, as we prefer to call it now, was given to us. [Sweetly, quietly.] Did not your own evil work against you? Did not the jealousy between yourselves and the worshippers of that other demon relinquish the fortress to us in your stead?
Turn around, my child, but do not turn around in the darkness.  Look to the light, learn from it.

As for you, good knights and good adventurers--Might you not consider turning around yourselves? This place is blessed by Amaunator, by the Risen Sun himself. Your goddess--[Smiling]--Why do you call her a goddess, when she is but the angel of Amaunator?--has kept this spot for him.

No, Theophilus.  You are misled.  The Flame Stone is a symbol of the link between Faerun and the realm of the divine, between earthly love and heavenly love.  It belongs neither to Bane's forces of tyranny nor this ancient god of yours.
Indeed, Theophilus.  You may have your beliefs, but you cannot impose them on those who have held this ground for centuries.
Is there some king or prince to whom I should make supplication?  Does this land belong to any realm?  If not, then on whom can I call except Amaunator?
We are not fools.  You come here armed; you do not mean to talk us out of this; nor will we yield in any way.

I concede that the arms of men are but toys, and the wars of men disgraceful. But there is no dignity except in serving Amaunator, and because this place is holy to him, our warfare, too, is holy and dignified. Is there a peaceful solution to this disagreement?

[To Ianth, pointedly.] There is no earthly love, Milady. There is only the love that surpasses the love of man; all else is a mockery, and is bound to lead us astray. The fire that has burned out shows the subservience of earthly love to that of the spirit--to that of Amaunator.
[A new figure appears at the western edge of the circle. You recognize your fellow Harper, Manfred.]
[Vroman blurts out--] My brother! I knew I would see you again before long--
[Turning with sudden quickness and fierceness.] The Harper? The diviner? Here?! Oh, Amaunator, this day is indeed blessed. [As he begins to enter the circle to approach Manfred, Theophilus stops.]

All enemies of Sune who enter this circle will perish.  Turn back.  All of you--Banites, Amaunatori!--all of you who are not friends of the goddess or the Balance.  You will burn on entering this ring.
[Theophilus frowns, but then his countenance once more appears benevolent and placid.] Ah, my child. This is what you say--
And yet I walk on grass as cold and dewy as any that covers Faerun. No fire descends upon me, no wrathful goddess of love undoes me. There is no fire but Amaunator's; no love but his.
And you have something that belongs to him. [As Theophilus points at Manfred, Sune's Stag Warriors burst into flame.]
No.  I have given it up.  In a matter of moments, I will be dead--I will rest at long last.

Impossible. Do not think such lies can fool me. The Word cannot perish. If you do, it will be as easy for me to hear as the glorious sun is to see. [More sweetly.] If you share it with me, now, as I told you to do so long ago, you will live. We will all live, by the power of the Word--in the Kingdom of Amaunator!
But I have already shared the Word with someone else. [Manfred looks at you and smiles. Theophilus follows his gaze.]

[A number of things happen at once: Manfred opens his arms and bursts into flame; Vroman cries out and runs to him; as he does, the scene before you changes drastically. The troops vanish; only your party and Theophilus remain. The sky goes grey and then is awash with brilliant light; fires spring up in the grass around you.]
[A new figure appears at the western edge of the circle. It is Manfred.]
You vile bitch.  Flee--you and all of your fawning soldiers!--, or you shall be the first to fall.

I will take your head myself for saying so, fool.  You were hardly a part of the quarrel we have with the group that calls itself the Risen Sun.  The misstep that brought you here at this hour was your last.
